Suzman once chased a Nobel-winning psychologist through a Washington rainstorm, as a scientific meeting was breaking up, to whet the psychologist’s interest in a new project. The old school logic there was that it would make it easier for her to sleep, which would, in turn, help her healing process and, more importantly, help her exhausted mother get some sleep. I never took them up on the idea, but I have to say that, after doing this puzzle, their suggestion sounds fairly benign.

abstract: ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, on Thursday lowered profit expectations for the year and said it had lost $700 million in the first quarter.
snippet: ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, on Thursday lowered profit expectations for the year and said it had lost $700 million in the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steel maker, on Thursday lowered profit expectations for the year and said it had lost $700 million in the first quarter as a recovery in Europe failed to offset a sharp drop in prices for iron ore and steel. The company also said its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, which is a more closely watched metric than net income in the industry, had fallen to $1.4 billion for the quarter. Earnings were $1.8 billion in the same period a year earlier. “We faced a number of headwinds,” Lakshmi Mittal, the company’s chief executive, said. The company, based in Luxembourg, cut the lower end of its guidance range for that pretax measure of earnings to $6 billion from $6.5 billion. Revenue for the first quarter was $17.1 billion, compared with $19.8 billion in the same period a year earlier.

headline.main: World’s Largest Steel Maker Loses $700 Million in Quarter

The cuts bring the number of layoffs this year to almost 12,000 out of a global work force of 340,000, or a reduction of 3.5 percent. Half of the cuts will be in Germany. From January to March, sales rose 8 percent to €18 billion, but the gain was because of the weaker euro.

Tests revealed that the culprit was a large growth entangled in his spinal cord, compressing the nerves that control lower parts of his body. It took two neurosurgeries at a Chicago hospital to remove the mass and 44 days of rehab before Mr. Vardeman, 62, could return to his home in Chesterton, Ind.

abstract: The Bank of England said it expected British consumer prices, which have been stuck at a zero percent inflation rate for two months, to pick up by the end of the year as the economy gathers steam.
snippet: The Bank of England said it expected British consumer prices, which have been stuck at a zero percent inflation rate for two months, to pick up by the end of the year as the economy gathers steam.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England said on Wednesday that it expected Britain’s inflation rate, which has been stuck at zero for two months, to pick up by the end of the year as the economy gathers steam. The central bank trimmed its economic growth forecast for the year to 2.5 percent, from an earlier estimate of 2.9 percent. But the revision reflects the low growth in the first quarter — 0.3 percent — which was short of the bank’s estimate of 0.6 percent. The inflation rate will rise to 0.6 percent by the end of 2015, the bank predicted. Its policy target is an annual inflation rate of 2 percent, which is deemed a healthy sign of economic growth.

headline.main: Bank of England Expects Zero Inflation Rate to Pick Up
headline.print_headline: Bank of England Expects Inflation Rate to Pick Up

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Every night, Aaron Melocik, a software developer, follows a precise food routine. He blends together half a gallon of water, three and a half tablespoons of macadamia nut oil and a 16-ounce bag of powder called Schmoylent. Then he pours the beige beverage into jars and chills them before bringing the containers to work the next day at Metrodigi, an education technology start-up.

abstract: A new book by two reporters from The Globe and Mail offers details about the emotional and business turmoil surrounding BlackBerry’s near collapse.
snippet: A new book by two reporters from The Globe and Mail offers details about the emotional and business turmoil surrounding BlackBerry’s near collapse.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis stepped down as co-chairmen and co-chief executives of BlackBerry, neither has spoken much in public about the once-dominant smartphone maker’s fall into near market obscurity. The two and many others have opened up, however, to two reporters from The Globe and Mail in Toronto: Jacquie McNish, a senior business writer and author of several books and Sean Silcoff, who reports about the company. The resulting book, “Losing the Signal: The Untold Story Behind the Extraordinary Rise and Spectacular Fall of BlackBerry,” which will be published in the United States on Tuesday, fills in some details of the early history of BlackBerry. And its later chapters offer gripping details about the emotional and business turmoil surrounding its near collapse.

headline.main: Behind the Downfall at BlackBerry
headline.print_headline: Book Details BlackBerry’s History and the Turmoil of Its Near Collapse

snippet: Two vacancies give the regulator a chance to add market expertise. Critics may gripe about the revolving door, but it pays to know how the financial world works.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission will soon have two top vacancies, and a Wall Street pedigree would be a plus for new watchdogs. Nominees with financial industry ties might prompt gripes about the revolving door, but it pays to know how the market works.

headline.main: Why the S.E.C. Could Use Commissioners With Wall Street Experience

abstract: Barred by a settlement from practicing journalism about the entertainment industry online, Ms. Finke is writing fiction for her new website, Hollywood Dementia.
snippet: Barred by a settlement from practicing journalism about the entertainment industry online, Ms. Finke is writing fiction for her new website, Hollywood Dementia.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If Nikki Finke had not been a journalist, she says she could have been a detective. The police in New York, where she reported decades ago, used to show her “these gruesome homicide photos,” she said, to try to freak her out. Instead she found them fascinating.

headline.main: Nikki Finke, Feared Hollywood Reporter, Turns to Fiction
headline.print_headline: Feared Hollywood Reporter Turns to Fiction

abstract: Samuel A. Donaldson and Brad Wilber are back, and they are out to get me.
snippet: Samuel A. Donaldson and Brad Wilber are back, and they are out to get me.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes you get the puzzle, and sometimes the puzzle gets you. This was a tough one for me, and it’s all because 1) I got excited that I finally recognized a rebus in a puzzle that didn’t actually contain one and 2) I momentarily conflated two characters in a famous television series that was nearly before my time.

headline.main: Noted Employee of Slate

lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Unlike the New York City subway system, this acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon showed up on time, was incredibly clean and did not emit a strange odor, and was easy to solve. abstract: Ultrafast Internet access is spreading unevenly throughout the world. And not getting that kind of broadband access could mean some communities miss out on significant economic opportunity.
